School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Yangzhou University Siwangting Road 180 225002 Yangzhou PR China Graphical abstract The development of heterogeneous catalysts for the difunctionalization of olefins is of great scientific significance because of their sustainability in the manufacturing industry. Herein, we report a ligand free Pd@TiO2 catalyst that realized the perfluoroalkyl carbonylation of terminal olefins using carbon monoxide as the C1 source, providing sustainable access to β-perfluoroalkyl esters. This catalyst shows high activity, good recyclability, and broad functional group tolerance. The catalytic system developed here can reduce noble metal use and avoid using precious homogeneous phosphorus ligands, which are also toxic to the environment. Keywords Carbonylation Alkenes Heterogeneous catalysis Palladium Titanium oxide Data availability I have share the data as supporting information 1 Introduction Esters, important carbonyl-containing compounds, widely exist in various natural and pharmaceutical products and are also useful building blocks in organic synthesis. [1–4] Compared with traditional esterification of carboxylic acids, transition metal-catalyzed carbonylation of olefins has emerged as an effective and attractive process because multi-component carbonylation of olefin will lead to multi-functionalized esters. [5–9] The fluorinated compounds, which have unique properties in medicinal chemistry and material chemistry, have attracted increasing attention [10–11]. Therefore, the development of a new strategy for the construction of fluorine-containing esters is still highly desired. The transition metal-catalyzed carbonylation reactions of alkenes or alkynes to esters have been well developed. However, precious phosphorous or nitrogen ligands are always necessary (Scheme 1 a). [12] The difunctionalization of unsaturated carbon–carbon bonds is a superb way to introduce fluoro and carbonyl groups into one molecular. [13–17] For example, homogeneous palladium-catalyzed fluoroalkylation and carbonylation of alkynes to construct β-difluoroalkyl unsaturated esters using CO or formate as C1 source have been reported (Scheme 1b). [18–20] Recently, another perfluoroalkylative carbonylation of olefins to β-perfluoroalkyl esters enabled by homogeneous Pd(OAc)2/BINAP [21] or Co(acac)2/PyBOX/Zn [22] catalysis was also demonstrated by Wu and Beller's group, respectively. (Scheme 1b). Although these homogeneous palladium systems show high activity and selectivity, the high catalyst loading and the utilization of expensive phosphorus or nitrogen ligands will limit their further application in industrial production. From a green and sustainable chemistry perspective, the recovery and reuse of homogeneous catalysts from the reaction mixture is a long-standing and intractable problem. Especially in the pharmaceutical industry, metal residue and purification are the main issues and challenges. So far, various supports（carbon, [23–24] metal oxides, [25–27] porous polymers [28–32], etc.）based catalysts have been reported for direct carbonylation of unsaturated carbon–carbon bonds. However, these established catalytic systems suffer narrow substrate scope, high temperature, or high pressure. Herein, we report a novel and efficient ligand-free heterogeneous Pd@TiO2 catalyst for the chemoselective synthesis of β-perfluoroalkyl esters through difunctionalization of terminal alkenes under mild and green conditions (Scheme 1c). The catalyst can maintain good activity after five cycles without noticeable activity loss. This heterogeneous palladium catalyst shows a broad substrate scope and excellent recycling performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Initially, a series of palladium catalysts supported on inorganic supports, e.g., TiO2, Al2O3, MgO, ZnO, ZrO2, and Fe3O4 were prepared by calcination of the mixture of metal precursor, ligand, and support at 300–––500 °C with or without triphenylphosphine as ligands under nitrogen, hydrogen or air atmosphere (see supporting information). All materials were prepared on 1 g scale and applied for the perfluoroalkylative carbonylation of terminal alkenes. 2.2 Characterization The morphology of catalyst was examined by a Tecnai G2 F30 S-TWIN high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). High resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were recorded on a Bruker Daltonics maXis Q-TOF (APCI and ESI). NMR spectra were recorded from an Agilent DD2 400 MHz spectrometer, instrument and calibrated using residual non-deuterated solvent (TMS: δH = 0 ppm, CDCl3: δC = 77.00 ppm) as an internal reference. GC–MS data were collected on Agilent 5977. GC analyses were conducted with a Shimadzu GC-2014 equipped with SH-1 glass capillary column and an FID detector. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an ESCALAB 250Xi with an Al-Kα radiation source, and the binding energies were calibrated as referenced to C 1 s (BE = 284.8 eV). Crystalline structures were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE with Cu Kα radiation at 2θ angle between 5 and 80◦. 2.3 Catalytic test A 5 mL screw-cap vial was charged with phenol (18.8 mg, 0.2 mmol), potassium carbonate (55.3 mg, 0.4 mmol), Pd@TiO2-400-H2 (20 mg), 1-octene (63 μL, 0.4 mmol), perfluorobutyl iodide (65 μL, 0.4 mmol) and 1.0 mL 1,4-dioxane. The vial was closed by rubber septum cap and connected with a needle. Then, the vial was fixed in an alloy plate and put into SLM250 autoclave (250 mL, Beijing Century Senlong). The reactor was purged with N2 (20 bar) three times, and then flushed with CO to 30 bar. The reaction was heated under 80 °C for 20 h. Afterwards, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the CO was carefully released. The internal standard dodecane (50 μL) was added and the sample was analyzed by gas chromatography. Pure product was obtained by column chromatography on silica gel. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of reaction conditions We commenced our study by using 1-octene (1a), perfluorobutyl iodide (2a), and phenol (3a) with 30 bar carbon monoxide in the presence of K2CO3 in 1,4-dioxane at 80 °C (Table 1 ). Initially, catalysts prepared through calcination of palladium/triphenylphosphine on different supports were tested, and most of the reactions showed inefficiency. However, the palladium/triphenylphosphine on TiO2 catalyst calcinated at 400 °C gave product 4 in 99 % yield (Table 1, entry 1). To our delight, the catalyst without ligand addition exhibited good activity for this transformation (Table 1, entry 2). Variation of the calcination temperature showed 400 °C is the optimal temperature (Table 1, entries 2–4). The catalysts calcinated under nitrogen atmosphere furnished the same activity while the catalyst prepared under air atmosphere gave only 66 % yield (Table 1, entries 5–6). Then, several solvents DCE, CH3CN, THF, anisole, and 1,4-dioxane were tested with Pd@TiO2-400-H2. The corresponding β-perfluoroalkyl ester product 4 can be obtained in 97 % yield in 1,4-dioxane (Table 2 , entries 1–5). Only trace products can be detected when DMSO is employed as the solvent (Table 2, entry 6). Different bases were screened in 1, 4-dioxane as the solvent. Potassium phosphate could deliver 93 % yield (Table 2, entry 8), and the yields were decreased significantly with other bases (Table 2, entries 7, 9–10). Reducing the pressure of CO to 20 bar led to a slightly lower yield (Table 2, entry 11). Reducing the catalyst amount to 10 mg, 46 % yield was detected (Table 2, entry 12). Increasing the catalyst amount to 30 mg, 86 % yield was detected (Table 2, entry 13). The reaction temperature can influence the activity, and 80 °C is the best choice (Table 2, entries 14–15). 3.2 Characterization of the optimal catalyst A detailed structural characterization of this material was performed to understand the superior activity of Pd@TiO2-400-H2. The palladium content of Pd@TiO2-400-H2 was determined as 5.10 wt% by ICP-OES. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) powder diagram showed a typical anatase TiO2 (JCPDS card no.99-0008), but the characteristic diffraction peak of Pd was not found in the diagram, which may attribute to the low loading, small size, and good dispersion of palladium on TiO2 (Scheme 2 ). Other materials prepared under different calcination gases and different temperatures show a similar structure. HRTEM pictures of the Pd@TiO2-400-H2 disclosed no aggregation of Pd NPs, while Pd was uniformly dispersed on TiO2 (Scheme 3 a, b). In Scheme 3b, it can be clearly observed that the lattice stripe spacing of 0.355 nm corresponds to the (101) crystal plane of anatase TiO2. Scheme 3c shows that the average size of Pd NPs is about 5–7 nm according to the particle size statistics of Pd NPs in Scheme 3a. In order to further explain that Pd is successfully loaded on TiO2, we analyzed the catalyst's EDX and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) spectra. We found the Pd on the EDS (Scheme 3d) spectra, which proved that Pd was successfully introduced into support TiO2. Through the spectral analysis of EDX mapping (Scheme 3e-h), it can be found that O (red), Pd (green), and Ti (yellow) are evenly distributed. To further understand the surface chemical composition of Pd@TiO2-400-H2, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded. In the Ti 2p spectra of the catalyst, the electron-binding energy of 464.5 eV and 458.8 eV were observed, which matched well with the Ti4+ 2p1/2 and Ti4+ 2p3/2 states, respectively (Scheme 4 b). [33] In Scheme 4c, two main peaks of Pd0 3d5/2 and Pd0 3d3/2 state at 335.0 eV and 340.3 eV. Peaks at 335.9 eV and 341.4 eV can be assigned to Pd (PdOx) intermediates 3d5/2 and 3d3/2. [34] After analysis and processing, the proportion of Pd0 in it is about 61 %. In comparison, the proportion of Pd0 catalyst calcined under nitrogen gas is only 27 % (Scheme 4d). Additionally, for Pd@TiO2-400-H2, two peaks of O 1 s (530.1 eV and 531.6 eV) can be assigned to the lattice oxygen of Ti–O and hydroxyl oxygen on the surface (Scheme 4a). [35]. 3.3 Substrate scope With the best reaction conditions, we explored the scope of the substrates for this heterogeneous multi-component carbonylation (Scheme 5 ). Firstly, the substitution of different functional groups in the ortho-position of phenols (5–7), including methoxy, phenyl, and acetyl could afford the related products in medium to excellent yields. Substitution of acetyl (8) in the meta-position of phenol could also reach 90 % yield. Both electron-donating substituents such as methyl (9), methoxy (10), methylthio (11), acetamido (12), dimethylphenyl (13) and electron-withdrawing substituents such as formyl (14), ester (15), bromo (16), cyano (17), and acetyl (18) on the para-position were well coupled, giving the target products in 76–93 % yields with excellent selectivity. Other multi-substituted phenols with more steric hindrance are tolerated under this catalytic system (19–24), although slightly decreased yields were found. In addition, some aliphatic alcohols can also obtain products with moderate yields (25–26). Gratifyingly, biologically active phenols, including Sesamol and Estrogen, reacted well and delivered the corresponding products with moderate yields (27–28). Besides, diphenol could be successfully transformed into a carbonylated compound (29–32). Later, other perfluoroalkyl halides and olefins were tested under standard conditions. Several perfluoroalkyl iodides can produce the products (33–35) in excellent yields (86–94 %). The long-chain alkenes were compatible under this heterogeneous catalytic system with 86–95 % yields (36–39). Allyl substrates such as 4-allyl anisole (40), and allyl benzene (41) provided products with moderate yields. Furthermore, alkenes bearing remote Vitamin E and Estrogen moieties are compatible, and the carbonylation products were obtained in moderate yields (42–43). 3.4 Mechanism study In order to understand the reaction mechanism, several controlled experiments were conducted (Scheme 6 ). When free radical inhibitor 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidoxyl (TEMPO) (1 equiv.) was added to the standard reaction mixtures, no β-perfluoroalkyl esters product was detected. However, 4 equiv. butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) is necessary to inhibit the reaction with 51 % yield. These results indicate that this perfluoroalkylative carbonylation may proceed through a free radical pathway. The direct use of compound 44 as the substrate instead of 1a and 2a under standard conditions gave 95 % yield of the product. This experiment supports that the compound 44, the addition product of olefin with perfluorobutyl iodide, might be the intermediate for this reaction. We propose the following mechanisms based on the control experiments and previous reports (Scheme 7 ). First, perfluoroalkyl halides are dehalogenated to generate perfluoroalkyl radicals, which are added to olefins to generate radical intermediate A. Then radical intermediate A is captured by catalyst Pd@TiO2-400-H2 to form intermediate B. Then it undergoes carbon monoxide insertion to form intermediate D. Nucleophiles will attack intermediate D in the presence of a base. Finally, reductive elimination will lead to the target product. It is worth noting that intermediate B can be transformed into intermediate C, which is conducive to being activated by the palladium catalyst to form intermediate B. To determine the active site in the catalyst, XPS measurements were done for the catalyst calcinated at different atmospheres (See supporting information). Most palladium exists as zero valence for the catalyst calcinated under hydrogen/nitrogen atmosphere. In contrast, almost all palladium was found as Pd2+ when it was calcinated under air. Therefore, the Pd0 should be the real active site to furnish the catalytic cycle, while the catalyst prepared in the presence of hydrogen gave the highest yield [21]. 3.5 Catalyst recycling To evaluate the recyclability of this Pd@TiO2-400-H2 catalyst, we carried out the recycling experiment with 1-octene (1a), perfluorobutyl iodide (2a) and phenol (3a) under standard conditions. The activity of the catalyst is almost unchanged after five cycles (Scheme 8 a). The slight decrease in yield may be attributed to the inevitable loss of catalyst after washing. Although the recycled catalyst characterized by ICP-OES showed the Pd loading was 3.50 wt%, the activity is unchanged obviously because the real active Pd sites should be stable on TiO2. Then, XPS characterization of the recovered catalyst revealed that only the characteristic peak of Pd0 was observed in the 3d spectrum of Pd (Scheme 8b). Then HRTEM characterization of the recovered catalyst discloses that the catalyst's morphology remains unchanged, and Pd nanoparticles are still dispersed uniformly (Scheme 8c-g). 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a series of heterogeneous TiO2-supported ligand-free Pd catalysts. Thereinto, Pd@TiO2-400-H2 catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic performance for the multi-component synthesis of β-perfluoroalkyl esters from olefin, perfluoroiodine alkanes, phenols with carbon monoxide as C1 source. A radical process is involved in this heterogeneous catalytic alkene difunctionalization to construct two carbon–carbon bonds simultaneously. This heterogeneous palladium catalyst accomplished high activity, good recyclability, and broad functional group compatibility. Ligand-free and good recycling performance will facilitate the application of industrial production. Further applications of Pd NPs on TiO2 catalysts are currently under investigation in our laboratory. Guodong Zhang: Writing – review & editing. Xiao-Feng Wu: Conceptualization, Resources, Writing – review & editing. Feng Chen: Conceptualization, Project administration, Supervision, Resources, Writing – review & editing. coredata.dc:description: The development of heterogeneous catalysts for the difunctionalization of olefins is of great scientific significance because of their sustainability in the manufacturing industry. Herein, we report a ligand free Pd@TiO2 catalyst that realized the perfluoroalkyl carbonylation of terminal olefins using carbon monoxide as the C1 source, providing sustainable access to β-perfluoroalkyl esters. This catalyst shows high activity, good recyclability, and broad functional group tolerance. The catalytic system developed here can reduce noble metal use and avoid using precious homogeneous phosphorus ligands, which are also toxic to the environment.
coredata.dc:title: Development of ligand-free Pd@TiO2 catalyst for efficient perfluoroalkylative carbonylation of terminal alkenes
